raw_comment: Looking at the graph, I immediately notice that young men in this survey reach out to parents noticeably less than the young women who were surveyed. With such a large disparity between the men and the women, I wonder how representative these results are for young men and women. Since the data was gathered via online survey over a relatively short time frame, I think the results might not be able to be generalized to young men and women in general. Whether or not the results are generalizable, knowing these statistics about the strength of relationships between parent and child is useful knowledge to have. There is a large amount of information regarding mental health issues in young adults, and cross referencing with data like this has the possibility to give insights to other broader issues. A title for this could be "Screen Age: How Electronics have Impacted Parental Communication"

The online survey happened over a relatively short time frame.
I think that the results might not be generalizable to young men and young women in general.
The results may be not generalizable.
Knowing these statistics about the strength of relationships between a parent and a child is useful knowledge.
There is much information about mental health issues in young adults.
A person can cross-reference this data with mental-health information.
Cross-referencing this data with mental-health information can give insights into broader issues.
The title is: "Screen Age: How electronics have impacted parental communication".
